Tony's academic pursuits took him to St. John's College, Oxford, where he graduated with a Bachelor's degree in Law. During his time at Oxford, he was heavily involved in student politics and served as the President of the Oxford University Conservative Association.

He was elected to the British House of Commons in 1983 as the Member of Parliament for Sedgefield, a constituency in northeast England. Tony's tenure as Prime Minister was marked by his close relationships with world leaders, including US President Bill Clinton and French President Jacques Chirac. He played a key role in several international crises, including the Yugoslav Wars and the Iraq War.

Tony Blair stepped down as Prime Minister in 2007, serving as the Leader of the Opposition until 2010. He has since founded the Tony Blair Institute for Global Change, a think tank focused on global politics, conflict resolution, and sustainability.
